    Design, Structural Optimization, and Characterization of the First Selective Macrocyclic Neurotensin Receptor Type 2 Non-opioid Analgesic

    • Magali Chartier
      Magali Chartier

    SUBJECTS:
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Neurophysiology,
    • Monomers,
    • Rodent models,
    • Receptors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Neurotensin (NT) receptor type 2 (NTS2) represents an attractive target for the development of new NT-based analgesics. Here, we report the synthesis and functional in vivo characterization of the first constrained NTS2-selective macrocyclic NT analog. While most chemical optimization studies rely on the NT(8-13) fragment, we focused on NT(7-12) as a scaffold to design NTS2-selective macrocyclic peptides. Replacement of Ile12 by Leu, and Pro7/Pro10 by allylglycine residues followed by cyclization via ring-closing metathesis led to macrocycle 4, which exhibits good affinity for NTS2 (50 nM), high selectivity over NTS1 (>100 μM), and improved stability compared to NT(8-13). In vivo profiling in rats reveals that macrocycle 4 produces potent analgesia in three distinct rodent pain models, without causing the undesired effects associated with NTS1 activation. We further provide evidence of its non-opioid antinociceptive activity, therefore highlighting the strong therapeutic potential of NTS2-selective analogs for the management of acute and chronic pain.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Opioids are widely used as analgesics for the treatment of various types of pain.(1,2) However, opioids like morphine may not be as effective for the management of neuropathic or bone cancer pain.(3−7) In addition, long-term use and dose escalation of opioids are associated with numerous adverse effects, namely, constipation, respiratory depression, and tolerance.(8,9) Furthermore, opioid prescribing has the potential to lead to patient abuse and misuse of these medications, which include addiction, overdoses, and death.(10−12) Drug alternatives are therefore needed to provide patients suffering from chronic pain with safe and effective pain medication.
    Neurotensin (NT), which possesses the sequence pGlu-Leu-Tyr-Glu-Asn-Lys-Pro-Arg-Arg-Pro-Tyr-Ile-Leu-OH, is a tridecapeptide secreted in the brain and gastrointestinal tract and was first isolated in 1973 from bovine hypothalami.(13) The hexapeptide C-terminal fragment NT(8-13) was then rapidly identified as the minimal amino acid sequence required for functional activity.(14) In recent years, peptide optimization and conjugation strategies have provided direct evidence of the analgesic potency and efficacy of NT(8-13) analogs, including the management of neuropathic pain for which opioid medications have shown limited long-term effectiveness.(15−17) Of particular importance, NT and its analogs produce opioid-independent antinociceptive responses,(18−23) and their combination with morphine leads to additive or synergistic analgesic actions.(24−26) Two G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) subtypes, namely, NTS1 and NTS2, have been shown to mediate the antinociceptive effects of NT.(27−30) Aside its role in pain modulation, activation of NTS1 was also associated with other central or peripheral actions, including hypotension and cardiovascular regulation, hypothermia, and modulation of gastrointestinal motility.(31−35) In contrast, the expression of NTS2 is almost exclusively restricted to the central nervous system, which makes this receptor an attractive target for the development of novel analgesic drugs with limited unwanted peripheral effects.(36−39)
    During the past two decades, technological advances in solving the structures of membrane proteins have facilitated the progress in GPCR crystallography, with now over 270 resolved crystal structures of 53 distinct receptors distributed across all four major GPCR classes.(40) Accordingly, several high-resolution X-ray crystal structures of the rNTS1 receptor have been solved in complex with NT(8-13), delineating the molecular determinants of ligand–receptor interactions.(41−44) In addition, cryo-EM structures of the hNTS1 were recently solved in complex with β-arrestins 1 and 2 or the heterotrimeric Gαi1β1γ2 protein in the presence of NT(8-13) or the homologous synthetic peptide KKPYIL.(45−47) These structural advances in the field of NT have therefore allowed to optimize the 3D structure of NTS2 by homology modeling and have opened new opportunities to identify novel chemotypes and rationally design NTS2-selective compounds.(48)
    To date, different chemical strategies have been used to improve receptor binding affinity and selectivity toward NTS2 as well as peptide stability and permeability. Among these approaches, substitution of the tyrosine residue in position 11 by natural (lysine) or unnatural amino acids (d-Trp, d-Tyr, (R)-Nal, d-3,1-Nal, 6-OH-Tic, Dmt, mTyr, N-hTyr, (R)-FPTyr, and (RTrans)TAA(OH)) has been found to favor NTS2 selectivity.(24,48−55) Accordingly, molecular dynamics simulations revealed that conformational changes and flexibility in Tyr11 are required for NTS1 activation by NT, thus reinforcing the crucial role played by Tyr11 in NTS1/NTS2 selectivity.(56)
    Compared to linear peptides, macrocyclic compounds have emerged as an important class of therapeutics by combining favorable properties, such as enhanced conformational rigidity, improved pharmacokinetic properties, and increased target selectivity and binding affinity.(57−59) Peptide cyclization has shown great success toward generating active NT analogs targeting NTS1 (Figure 1). Indeed, head-to-tail (M1 and M2), head-to-side-chain (M3, M4, and M5), and side-chain-to-side-chain (M6 and M7) peptide cyclization of NT(8-13) have all provided macrocyclic analogs with relatively high affinities for NTS1, ranging from 16 nM to 3.5 μM.(60−63) Of particular note, most of these cyclic analogs of NT(8-13) were found to behave as NTS1 agonists using in vitro functional assays (except M7, which seems to act as an antagonist).(61) Furthermore, M2 and its dimeric counterpart M8 showing similar binding affinity for both NTS1 and NTS2 (150 nM) were further found to exhibit in vivo biological activity, inducing hypothermic and analgesic effects following systemic administration.(62,64) Recently, we searched for optimized macrocyclization sites on NT(8-13) and found that macrocycles formed via ring-closing metathesis (RCM) between the side chains of alkene-functionalized amino acid in position 8 and the ortho allylated tyrosine residue in position 11 of NT(8-13) (M9-M12) showed greatly improved plasma stability, high binding affinity toward both NTS1 and NTS2, and potent analgesic action in vivo (Figure 1).(65,66) In the present study, we report the synthesis and in vitro characterization of the first constrained NTS2-selective macrocyclic NT analog. We further provide evidence of its non-opioid antinociceptive properties in different types of pain and lack of hypothermia and hypotensive activity.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Alanine Scan of NT

    In order to investigate which residues of NT(1-13) are important for binding to NTS1 and NTS2 and identify suitable sites for cyclization, an alanine scan was first performed. Alanine scanning has been proven successful in mapping essential amino acids in complex structures(67) and was therefore used here for NT as a way to explore the most important side chains for NTS2 selectivity. Every amino acid was successively replaced by l-alanine to observe the impact on receptor binding affinity. Binding affinities at the human NT receptors were determined using [125I]-Neurotensin competitive radioligand binding assays with membranes from Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells stably expressing NTS1 or 1321N1 astrocytoma cells stably expressing NTS2 (Table 1, Table S1, and Figure S1). According to previous findings showing that NT(8-13) possesses the full binding activity and in vivo potency of NT(1-13),(14,68) replacing residues in the 1-7 moiety of NT(1-13) by alanine did not significantly change the binding affinity for either receptor and did not affect selectivity toward NTS2. In contrast, changes in the 8-13 fragment of NT significantly impacted both affinity and selectivity. Indeed, the substitution of amino acids 11, 12, or 13 by Ala decreased binding affinities at both NTS1 and NTS2 by at least 100-fold. In addition, terminal amidation of NT(1-13) showed a 10-fold decrease in receptor binding affinity. In general, these changes seem to affect NTS1 to a greater extent than NTS2, suggesting that the latter exhibits a more permissive binding pocket. These results are in accordance with the literature that shows the importance of residues Tyr11, Ile12, and Leu13 for affinity, subtype selectivity, and functional activity.(50,68,69)
    Table 1. Alanine Scan of NT(1-13)a
     Ki (nM) 
    peptideNTS1NTS2selectivity for NTS2
    NT(1-13)3.3 ± 0.24.1 ± 0.80.8
    NT(1Ala)2.0 ± 0.58.7 ± 3.10.2
    NT(2Ala)2.4 ± 1.06.8 ± 1.60.3
    NT(3Ala)2.8 ± 1.08.7 ± 4.20.3
    NT(4Ala)1.8 ± 0.52.7 ± 1.10.7
    NT(5Ala)2.4 ± 0.78.8 ± 1.60.3
    NT(6Ala)6.0 ± 3.39.3 ± 4.70.6
    NT(7Ala)2.9 ± 0.74.6 ± 1.30.6
    NT(8Ala)75 ± 7.995 ± 440.8
    NT(9Ala)174 ± 2110 ± 3.117
    NT(10Ala)161 ± 3216 ± 7.49.9
    NT(11Ala)>10,000590 ± 370>17
    NT(12Ala)210 ± 49740 ± 2702.9
    NT(13Ala)>10,000655 ± 520>15
    NT-NH243 ± 1136 ± 191.2
    NT(8-12)>100,000620 ± 360>160
    NT(8-12Leu)>100,000391 ± 87>255
    a

    Binding affinity and selectivity of NT(1-13) analogs. Results are expressed as Ki values ± SEM, which are the mean of three independent experiments. Ki values were calculated using the Cheng–Prusoff equation(70) from IC50 values determined based on displacement curves of [125I]-Neurotensin on hNTS1 and hNTS2 membranes shown in Figure S1. Selectivity was calculated as the ratio of Ki between hNTS1 and hNTS2.

    Following the alanine scan, truncated linear NT analogs were also synthesized with the goal to identify a better scaffold for NTS2 selectivity. Critically, NT(8-12) (Ki > 100 μM on NTS1 and 620 nM for NTS2) showed no receptor binding to NTS1 while maintaining its ability to bind NTS2 with similar affinity as NT(13Ala) (Ki 655 nM, Table 1 and Figure S1). These results are congruent with previous observations made on NT(1-12)(68,69) and with the crystal structure of the NTS1-NT(8-13) complex, which shows that the Leu13 residue of NT(8-13) is connected to Y324, R327, and R328 through a hydrogen bond network.(43,44) This result suggests that removing the C-terminal amino acid therefore emerges as a potential avenue to improve selectivity in favor of NTS2. Furthermore, replacement of Ile12 by Leu (Ki 391 nM for NTS2 vs >100 μM for NTS1) also showed a greater effect on receptor selectivity, suggesting a potential role of steric hindrance surrounding the β position of amino acid in position 12. Residues 12 and 13 therefore emerge as a primary target toward the discovery of NT analogs selective for NTS2 since it disproportionally affects NTS1 affinity compared to NTS2. Following the identification of NT(8-12Leu) as a promising scaffold, we designed a series of macrocyclic peptides in order to synthesize constrained NTS2-selective compounds. Contextually, this is a paradigm shift in the field of NT since most optimization studies have been based on the C-terminal fragment 8-13, which is the minimal pharmacophoric element that conserves the pharmacological properties of NT.(14) The crucial role played by the tyrosine residue at position 11 in macrocyclic structure will also require further study. Indeed, as previously demonstrated using unnatural amino acids,(24,48−55) the alanine scan also reveals that modification of NT at Tyr11 is detrimental for NTS1, thus increasing the selectivity toward NTS2.

    Chemistry/Design and Synthesis

    Macrocyclic peptides were synthetized using Fmoc-based solid phase peptide synthesis (SPPS) on 2-chlorotrityl chloride resin following standard procedures (Figure 2 and Table S1).(65,66) Cyclization was performed on resin using ring-closing metathesis (RCM) between two allylglycine residues, using the Hoveyda–Grubbs second-generation catalyst based on its stability and tolerance to diverse functional groups.(65,66) Yields for the RCM step were assessed by UPLC-MS to be around 70%.
    Our first approach was to replace turn-inducing proline residues 7 and 10 by allylglycine residues to mediate cyclization. With the presence of these two proline residues, known to induce secondary structure changes in peptides, it was thought that macrocyclic restriction on these positions may similarly mimic turn structures and promote a productive conformation for NTS2 receptor binding.(71) Given the results of the alanine scan, which show a retention of selectivity when mutating the C-terminus of the peptide, we kept macrocyclization invariant while varying the C-terminal end. Being the natural amino acids found in NT, leucine and isoleucine residues were either used in positions 12 and 13 or deleted in position 13 (Table 2). The resulting macrocycles 1 (Ile12 and Leu13) and 2 (Leu12 and Ile13) did not show any affinity (Ki > 10 μM) for either receptor. Importantly, compound 4, truncated at position 13 and with the Ile12Leu replacement, displayed good affinity for NTS2 and not for NTS1 (Ki 50 nM for NTS2; selectivity >1600 vs NTS1; Table 2 and Figure S2), congruent with the alanine-scan results of NT(8-12Leu) (Table 1). Just as remarkably, its isomer with Ile in position 12 shows no binding to NTS2 (3, Ki > 10 μM).
    Table 2. Cyclization Sites, Binding Affinity, and Selectivity of Macrocyclic NT(8-13) Peptide Analogs at Both hNTS1 and hNTS2a
    a

    Results are expressed as Ki value ± SEM as the mean of three independent experiments. Ki values were calculated using the Cheng–Prusoff equation(70) from IC50 values determined based on displacement curves of [125I]-Neurotensin on hNTS1 and hNTS2 membranes shown in Figure S2. Selectivity was calculated as the ratio of Ki between hNTS1 and hNTS2. *Not based on NT notation.

    Several additional macrocycles were synthesized with the goal to delineate the structure–activity relationship (SAR) of compound 4. Other macrocyclization sites were first explored in order to test whether the secondary structure could be further modulated toward NTS2 selectivity. Newly synthesized compounds 5 and 7 did not possess affinity on NTS2 (Ki > 10 μM), while macrocycle 6 showed a significant loss but still activated the receptor (Ki 1.3 μM). Insertion of the proline residue at position 10 at either allylglycine site (8 and 9) did not improve binding affinity compared to compound 4. 8 showed a modest 4-fold decrease in binding affinity compared to 4 (Ki 0.2 μM compared to 0.05 μM), while 9 exhibited a more drastic 50-fold decrease in affinity (Ki 2.5 μM). We did not continue investigations on those molecules since their binding affinity was lower than that of compound 4.
    The affinity benefits of macrocyclization in this position could be interpreted as a conformational restriction of the backbone around Lys(9) and Lys10. This decrease in entropy could favor a certain sub-population of conformers around Lys(9) and Lys10, which could in turn facilitate interactions with residues at the entry of the binding site of NTS2. The absence of binding on NTS1 suggests that the presence of Arg212 in extracellular loop 2 (ECL2) could be of a great importance. Indeed, Arg212 is known to be an important residue for the binding process,(48) but considering the restriction of both lysine residues, it is possible that this interaction becomes detrimental. On the contrary, the same residue in NTS2 is mutated to Glu179, which could positively interact with constrained Lys(9) and Lys(10) and favor binding to NTS2.(48) Both lysine residues are known to point toward the entry of the ligand binding site, which could force interactions with the amino acid in position 179 and be beneficial in the case of NTS2.(43) In addition, the massive impact of Leu vs Ile in position 12 could possibly be interpreted in terms of steric hindrance and limited rotation of β-branching (Ile) vs γ-branching (Leu).
    Additional macrocycles were further synthesized to refine the SAR of macrocycle 4. Compounds 10–12 were prepared using d-allylglycine on either or both positions 7 and 10 (Table 2). Replacement of l-allyglycine for its d-stereoisomer in positions 7 and 11 individually and together was detrimental to binding affinity, except in position 7 where it had a less negative impact on NTS2 binding (11, Ki 0.1 μM vs 4, Ki 0.05 μM), suggesting that l-allylglycine offers optimal stereochemistry to maximize NTS2 binding (Table 2 and Figure S2). Reduction of the linker via hydrogenation (compound 13) had a marginal impact on binding (Ki 90 vs 50 nM), suggesting that linker flexibility is not very important for NTS2 binding. Finally, replacement of l-allylglycine by l-cysteine residues macrocyclized via a disulfide bridge produced significant reduction in binding affinity (14, Ki 1.5 μM vs 4, Ki 50 nM). It could be hypothesized that either lipophilicity or change in steric hindrance may be detrimental for NTS2 receptor binding.

    Stability in Plasma and Cerebrospinal Fluid

    Metabolic stability of the most promising NTS2-selective macrocycle (compound 4) was then assessed at 37 °C in plasma and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of naive rats, analyzing compound degradation by UPLC-MS (Table 3 and Figure S3). As previously observed, degradation of the native neurotensin peptide was very fast in plasma, with a half-life estimated of 1.6 ± 0.2 min.(65,72) However, its stability in CSF was superior, evaluated at 14.9 ± 3.0 h. This difference in half-life can be explained by the lower proteolytic activity in CSF compared to plasma.(73) Compound 4 showed increased plasma and CSF stability, reaching 15.0 ± 2.6 min and >24 h, respectively. This 15-fold increase in plasma half-life is probably due to macrocyclization, which is thought to induce a different secondary structure than the rapidly degraded beta-strand.(74) This cyclization also happens to be surrounding a known dibasic Lys8-Lys9 degradation site,(75) which has already been successfully protected by other chemical approaches, notably amide bond reduction(76) or incorporation of the unnatural amino acid β3hLys in position 8.(24,77,78) However, the stability of compound 4 is not optimal and can be further improved. Indeed, previous findings demonstrated that NT is rapidly degraded mainly between Arg8-Arg9 but also between Pro10-Tyr11 and Tyr11-Ile12 by a combination of three metalloendopeptidases, EC 3.4.24.11 (also known as neprilysin), EC 3.4.24.15 (Thimet oligopeptidase), and EC 3.4.24.16 (neurolysin).(79−81) The Pro10-Tyr11 site may already be protected by steric hindrance of the ring, unlike Tyr11-Ile12. Further work could be done in order to optimize plasma stability of macrocycle 4.
    Table 3. Stability in Rat Plasma and Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) of Compound 4a
    compoundt1/2 in plasma (min)t1/2 in CSF (h)
    NT(8-13)1.6 ± 0.214.9 ± 3.0
    415.0 ± 2.6>24
    a

    Half-life (t1/2) was calculated as the disappearance of half of the compound determined by UPLC-MS.

    Analgesic Properties

    The antinociceptive effect of compound 4 was first tested in an acute thermal nociceptive test. Measurement of its ability to increase the latency of the tail-flick response to thermal noxious stimuli was observed following intrathecal (i.t.) injection to Sprague-Dawley rats of increasing doses of macrocycle 4 ranging from 10 to 150 μg/kg (Figure 3). We found that i.t. delivery of 4 elicited a dose-dependent increase in tail-flick latency compared to saline-treated rats, demonstrating its antinociceptive properties (Figure 3A). Peak analgesic responses consistently occurred 10 min after injection of 4, while the highest doses of 90 and 150 μg/kg induced maximal elevation of the tail-flick threshold, reaching the predetermined 10 s cutoff time. Indeed, the analgesic efficacy of 4, expressed as the % of maximal possible effect (MPE), reached 13.1%, 32.5%, 73.1%, 98.6%, and 98.5% at doses of 10, 30, 60, 90, and 150 μg/kg, respectively (Figure 3B). The resulting 50% effective dose (ED50) was estimated at 43.8 μg/kg (Figure 3C). For comparison purposes, the analgesic potency of macrocycle 4 was similar to that of other NTS2-selective linear NT(8-13) analogs, such as JMV431 (Boc-Arg-Arg-Pro-Tyr-ψ(CH2NH)-Ile-Leu-OH) or NT79 (NαMeArg-Arg-Pro-d-3,1-Nal-tLeu-Leu).(82,83) In the same experimental pain paradigm, compound 4 was, however, less potent than the macrocyclic analog M12, which exhibits an ED50 of 4.6 μg/kg (Figure 1).(66) Nevertheless, the analgesic efficacy of 4 was considerably higher than that of M12, inducing maximal elevation of the tail-flick threshold at the highest dose tested (98.5% MPE) compared to 50% MPE for M12. These differences in analgesic response might be explained by the ability of M12 to bind to both NTS1 (Ki 15 nM) and NTS2 (Ki 4.5 nM) receptors.(66) In the same radiant heat tail-flick test, subcutaneous administration of morphine produced a dose-dependent antinociceptive effect with an ED50 of 3.6 mg/kg, achieving 83.3% MPE at the highest dose tested (Figure 3D–F). However, the analgesic efficacy of morphine observed at 10 mg/kg was accompanied by unfavorable side effects, such as drowsiness, constipation, and respiratory depression. Importantly, we also found here that the analgesic effect of 4 was not reversed by the opioid antagonist, naloxone (Figure 3G,H). This is in accordance with previous studies demonstrating that NT-induced analgesia operates independently of opioid receptor activity.(18,19,22,23,84)
    The antinociceptive effect of compound 4 was also evaluated in acute (formalin) and chronic inflammatory (complete Freund’s adjuvant, CFA) pain models. Following intraplantar injection of formalin into the right hind paw of saline-pretreated rats, a biphasic nociceptive behavioral response is observed, characterized by an acute phase (0–9 min) followed by a sustained inflammatory phase. Formalin-induced pain-related behaviors were quantified for the two phases by monitoring the duration of the nociceptive behavioral episodes, such as lifting, licking, biting, and shaking of the right injected hind paw.(85) Herein, we assessed the ability of compound 4 in reducing the formalin-evoked lifting behaviors, a stereotypical nociceptive response previously associated to NTS2 activation (Figure 4).(86) Our results revealed that compound 4 significantly reduced the formalin-induced pain behaviors in both acute and inflammatory phases, as previously shown with either NTS1, NTS2, or non-selective NT receptor agonists.(17,24,26,86−88)
    For comparison purposes, we used the macrocyclic drug ziconotide (also called Prialt or SNX-111), an approved non-opioid analgesic derived from a cone snail (Conus magus) that acts as a selective neuronal N-type voltage-sensitive calcium channel blocker.(89) We have tested this potent and stable cyclic conotoxin since its administration via the intrathecal and epidural routes is used for the management of severe chronic pain, particularly in cancer patients who are intolerant or refractory to systemic analgesics or to intrathecal morphine.(90−92) At the dose used clinically (1 μg/kg), ziconotide was found here to be as effective as macrocycle 4 in inhibiting the formalin-induced nociceptive responses (Figure 4). As opposed to 4, we, however, observed transient and reversible adverse effects following administration of ziconotide, such as dizziness, drowsiness, tremoring, ataxia, abnormal gait, and hyperactivity. These adverse events are also frequently reported in humans. In addition, ziconotide is also contraindicated in patients with pre-existing neuropsychiatric disorders and a history of cardiovascular disease.(91−94)
    We next assessed the antiallodynic effect of compound 4 in a chronic inflammatory pain model. To this end, mechanical allodynia was monitored using the von Frey test on days 3, 7, and 14 following unilateral injection of CFA into the plantar surface of the rat’s hind paw. Three days after CFA injection, the paw withdrawal threshold was significantly reduced compared to sham animals, indicating the presence of mechanical hypersensitivity (Figure 5A). Intrathecal injection of compound 4 on days 7 and 14 resulted in an increased paw withdrawal threshold compared to saline-treated rats, producing antiallodynic effects up to 45% at 150 μg/kg (Figure 5B,C). To our knowledge, this study is the first to demonstrate that activation of NTS2 receptors reduces the nociceptive behaviors to persistent inflammatory pain in a CFA-induced chronic inflammatory pain model.

    Other Physiological Effects

    Although NT analogs exert potent analgesic actions, they are also responsible for other physiological effects, which include hypotension, hypothermia, and modulation of gastrointestinal motility.(31−35) These peripheral and central effects, shown to be mediated by NTS1 receptors using knockout mice (NTS1–/–),(95−97) could represent serious limitations for the development of novel pain therapies. Here, we thus determined if compound 4, selective for the NTS2 receptor subtype, was devoid of these potential adverse effects.
    We first injected compound 4 to Sprague-Dawley rats and monitored variations in arterial blood pressure (ΔMABP) via direct and continuous intracarotid measurement (Figure 6A). As opposed to NT(8-13), which was found to produce a sharp and sustained drop in blood pressure, reaching up to 50 mmHg at 0.1 mg/kg, intravenous (i.v.) administration of 4 did not provoke hypotensive action. Even at 1 mg/kg i.v., compound 4 displayed only a slight and short-lasting hypertensive effect on blood pressure. This reflex response might be due to the stimulation of aortic and carotid baroreceptors of the autonomic nervous system or norepinephrine release in blood vessels, as previously reported following NT administration.(32,98) We next investigated whether compound 4 was able to induce change in body temperature following central administration (Figure 6B). In contrast to the NTS1-selective agonist PD149163 (30 μg/kg), which led to strong and persistent hypothermia, with a temperature drop of 3 °C following i.t. delivery, compound 4 injected at the highest dose (150 μg/kg) did not induce drop in body temperature. Finally, we determined whether compound 4 was able to modulate the intestinal smooth muscle contractions in isolated organ bath (Figure 6C). No change in ex vivo ileum contractile activity was noticed for compound 4 compared to NT(8-13), which dose-dependently induced ileum relaxation (EC50 = 3.9 nM), in accordance with previous findings.(99,100)

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the current study, we thus designed and synthesized a series of new NT macrocyclic analogs in order to explore the chemical space associated with NT receptor binding. Various side chain-to-side chain macrocyclizations were performed, and only the ring closure between the two amino acids surrounding the lysine residues 8 and 9 was effective in retaining high-affinity to NTS2. Moreover, replacement of the C-terminal Ile12-Leu13 residues by Leu12 was well tolerated by NTS2 while being detrimental to NTS1. This could possibly be interpreted by a more permissive NTS2 binding pocket and a lack of flexibility of the NTS1 receptor around amino acid 12. This is translated by a significant reduction in binding affinity of compound 3 compared to 4 and could be attributed to the steric hindrance around the β position of amino acid in position 12. The rigidity induced by macrocyclization also seems to favor the positioning of the lysine residues 8 and 9, which are very important for NT receptor binding, since the reduced form of RCM (i.e., 13) did not result in improved NTS2 receptor binding affinity. The use of RCM based on l-allylglycine was optimal in restraining lysine residues in a suitable position for NTS2 binding since their enantiomers in either position were found to affect NTS2 binding. The conformational changes in the peptide’s secondary structure also protected the dibasic Lys-Lys cleavage site from proteolytic degradation. More analogs will need to be synthesized in order to further explore the implication of β-branching (compound 3) compared to γ-branching (compound 4) in binding affinity toward NTS2.
    Finally, our results demonstrate that this constrained NTS2-selective macrocyclic analog was effective in reversing the thermal, chemical, and mechanical nociceptive behaviors in three distinct rodent pain models, without causing the usual undesired effects associated with NTS1 activation, i.e. hypotension, hypothermia, or ileum relaxation. Importantly, the analgesic effect of compound 4 was found to be mediated by an opioid-independent mechanism. Further studies are ongoing to more precisely understand the SAR and optimize their pharmacokinetic profile. Indeed, previously published literature suggests that metabolically stable NT analogs could produce central effects, including antinociception and hypothermia, probably through the increased blood circulation time, hence enhancing the blood–brain barrier penetration.(101) Altogether, we report here the synthesis of the first highly selective constrained macrocyclic NTS2 analog. Our results further highlight the strong therapeutic potential of NTS2-selective analogs, therefore offering a non-opiate pharmacotherapy option for the management of acute and chronic pain.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Peptide Synthesis

    Peptides were synthesized on solid phase using standard Fmoc chemistry using 200 mg of 2-chlorotrityl chloride resin (100–200 mesh dry, 0.25 mmol/g) from Matrix Innovation. All commercially available Fmoc-protected amino acid were purchased from Chem-Impex and Matrix Innovation at the highest purity available. Other reagents (coupling reagents, base) and solvents were purchased from Chem-Impex, Matrix Innovation, or Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received. Peptide synthesis was performed on an orbital shaker at 150 rpm in 6 mL polypropylene reactors with 20 μm frit purchased from Applied Separations.

    Standard Resin Wash Procedures

    After each step, the resin was washed for 1 min using alternating 5 mL volumes of DMF (x2), DCM (x2), iPrOH, DCM (x2), and DMF (x2). When a dried resin was needed, two additional washes with DCM or Et2O were performed followed by at least 5 min drying in vacuo.

    Loading of the First Amino Acid

    The resin and the first amino acid (1 eq. based on nominal loading, typically 0.25 mmol/g) were added to a 6 mL reactor. Five milliliters of DCM was then added and stirred for 5 min or until the amino acid was completely dissolved. 2 eq. of diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) was added to the mixture, which was then placed on the orbital shaker to react for 2 h or overnight. Unreacted sites on the resin were then capped with 5 mL of a 7/2/1 mixture of DCM/MeOH/DIPEA for 45 min. Standard wash procedure was applied.

    Fmoc Deprotection

    Fmoc deprotection was performed by adding 5 mL of a 20% solution of piperidine in DMF for 5 min, repeated once. Standard wash procedure was applied.

    Coupling of Standard Amino Acids

    A 5 eq. solution of Fmoc-protected amino acid and 5 eq. of hexafluorophosphate azabenzotriazole tetramethyluronium (HATU) were added to 5 mL of DMF and allowed to dissolve, sometimes with the help of sonication. The mixture was then added to the washed resin, and 6 eq. of DIPEA was added. The reactor was sealed, the internal pressure was released after gentle hand shaking once or twice, and then it was placed on the orbital shaker for 30–60 min.

    Coupling of Expensive Amino Acids

    A 2 eq. solution of Fmoc-protected amino acid and 2 eq. of HATU were added to 5 mL of DMF and allowed to dissolve, sometimes with the help of sonication. The mixture was then added to the washed resin, and 3 eq. of DIPEA were added. The reactor was sealed, the internal pressure was released after gentle hand shaking once or twice, and then it was placed on the orbital shaker for at least 2 h, sometimes overnight.

    Ring-Closing Metathesis

    To a flame-dried microwave vial with a stir bar was added 0.2 eq. of Hoveyda–Grubbs second-generation catalyst, 1 eq. of p-benzoquinone, and the previously dried resin. The solid mixture was then degassed with Ar for 10 min before adding 3 mL of DCE. The mixture was then subjected to microwave irradiation for 1 h at 70 °C on a CEM Discover microwave.

    Peptide Cleavage

    The previously dried resin was transferred to a glass vial to which was added 4 mL of a solution of TFA, water, and triisopropylsilane (95/2.5/2.5) and then shaken for 2 h. The mixture was filtered over a cotton plug into 30 mL of ice-cold methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE), resulting in compound precipitation. The mixture was centrifuged at 3000 rpm at 4 °C for 10 min. The remaining supernatant was analyzed by UPLC to confirm the absence of peptides in the organic phase and then was discarded. The crude precipitate was evaporated in vacuo.

    Lyophilization

    When lyophilized molecules were needed (after final purification, before disulfide bridge formation, etc.), the crude peptide was solubilized in a mix 1:1 of H2O:ACN and subsequently frozen in glass or polyethylene (PE) vials. The vials were slightly opened, and the PE tubes were perforated on the cap in order to let the gasses evacuate during lyophilization. The vials were put under vacuum until completely lyophilized, resulting in a solid.

    Disulfide Bridge Formation (Cys-Containing Macrocycles)

    To the previously cleaved and lyophilized peptide was added 1 mL/mg of a 70% AcOH aqueous solution, and the mixture was stirred until full dissolution. To this solution, under stirring, was added dropwise a solution of 10% I2 in MeOH until the solution remained yellow. The mixture was then frozen and lyophilized twice until a solid was obtained.

    Peptide Purification and HRMS Analysis

    To the previously lyophilized peptide was added 1.8 mL of 50% ACN in water. The following solution was then injected on a Waters preparative HPLC-MS (column XSELECTTM CSHTM Prep C18 (19 × 100 mm) packed with 5 μm particles, UV detector 2998, MS SQ Detector 2, Sample manager 2767, and binary gradient module). Eluents used were acetonitrile containing 0.03% aqueous ammonia and water containing 20 mM ammonium carbonate.
    A first run was done with the above eluents and the following method: 5% ACN to 95% ACN (0 → 10 min) in order to assess the optimal %ACN for product elution. A second run was made using the following eluent: [(%ACN) – 10 → (%ACN) + 5] (0 → 15 min). Fractions collected were analyzed on a Waters UPLC-MS system (column Acquity UPLC CSHTM C18 (2.1 × 50 mm) packed with 1.7 μm particles) using ACN and water + 0.1% formic acid. The method used was 0 → 0.2 min: 5% ACN; 0.2 → 1.5 min: 5% → 95% ACN; 1.5 → 1.8 min: 95% ACN; 1.8 → 2.0 min: 95% → 5% ACN; 2.0 → 2.5 min: 5% ACN. Pure fractions were pooled and lyophilized. All compounds possess ≥95% purity as determined by UPLC-MS. HRMS spectra of the peptides were recorded using a maXis ESI-Q-TOF with ESI in positive mode.

    Double Bond Reduction (Compound 13)

    To the previously purified peptide was added 0.1 mL/mg MeOH. A 1 eq. solution of palladium hydroxide was added. The mixture was then placed in a pressure hydrogen vessel under 100 psi of hydrogen pressure and stirred overnight. The mixture was then evaporated, resolubilized using 50% ACN/H2O, filtered, and purified on the previously described prep-MS.

    Competitive Radioligand Binding Assay on the hNTS1 and hNTS2 Receptors

    Membrane Cell Preparation

    CHO-K1 cells stably expressing hNTS1 (ES-690-C from PerkinElmer, Montréal, Canada) or 1321N1 cells stably expressing hNTS2 (ES-691-C from PerkinElmer, Montréal, Canada) were cultured in DMEM/F12 culture medium at 37 °C in a humidified chamber under 5% CO2. Culture media were supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 U/mL penicillin, 100 μg/mL streptomycin, 20 mM HEPES, and 0.4 mg/mL G418. Cells were frozen upon reaching 80% confluency. Those expressing hNTS1 were scrapped off the dish on ice with 10 mM Tris buffer and 1 mM EDTA at pH 7.5 and centrifuged at 15,000g for 5 min at 4 °C. The pellet was then re-suspended in 1 mL of binding buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.2% BSA). Those expressing hNTS2 were scraped off the dish with PBS and 0.5 mM EDTA at pH 7.5 and then sonicated for 5 min (pulse 30 s/5 s off, amplitude 40%) and ultracentrifuged at 100,000g for 60 min at 4 °C. The pellet was re-suspended in 1 mL of ice-cold buffer (PBS, glycerol, 0.5 mM EDTA), sonicated for 1 min (pulse 30 s/5 s off, amplitude 50%), and further diluted in binding buffer.

    Radioligand Binding Assay

    Competitive radioligand binding experiments were performed by pre-incubating 15 μg of cell membranes expressing the hNTS1 receptor with 45 pM 125I-[Tyr3]-NT (2200 Ci/mmol) or 50 μg of cell membranes expressing the hNTS2 receptor with 300 pM 125I-[Tyr3]-NT in binding buffer in the presence of increasing concentrations of analogs ranging from 10–11 to 10–4 M for 60 min at 25 °C. After incubation, the binding mixture was transferred in PEI-coated 96-well filter plates (glass fiber filters GF/B, Millipore, Billerica, MA). The reaction was terminated by filtration, and then plates were washed three times with 200 μL of ice-cold binding buffer. Glass filters were then counted using a γ-counter (2470 Wizard2, PerkinElmer, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada). Non-specific binding was measured in the presence of 10–5 M unlabeled NT(8-13) and represented less than 5% of total binding. Data were normalized compared to NT(8-13) to control for unwanted source of variation. IC50 values were determined from competition curves as the unlabeled ligand concentration inhibiting 50% of 125I-[Tyr3]-NT-specific binding. Ki values were determined using the Cheng–Prusoff equation from IC50 values.(70) Competitive radioligand binding data were plotted using the nonlinear regression One-site-Fit Log(IC50) and represented the mean ± SEM of three independent experiments, each performed in triplicate to ensure the reliability of single values.

    Plasma and Cerebrospinal Fluid Stability Assay

    Rats were anesthetized with 2.5% isoflurane for blood collection and with ketamine/xylazine (87 mg/kg: 13 mg/kg, i.m.) for CSF collection. Rat plasma was obtained by centrifugation of rat blood (13,000 rpm, 5 min, 4 °C). Rat CSF was collected from the cisterna magna. Compounds were solubilized in water (10 mM) and diluted to 1/10 ratio (1 mM) using water. Six microliters of the drug solution was incubated in 27 μL of rat plasma at 37 °C for 1, 3, 5, 10, and 20 min or rat CSF at 37 °C for 24 h. Proteolytic degradation was quenched by adding 70 μL of an aqueous solution containing 10% trichloroacetic acid and 0.5% nicotinamide followed by immediate vortexing. Samples were centrifuged (13,000 rpm, 15 min, 4 °C), and the supernatant was filtered on a 4 mm nylon 0.2 μm syringe filter and then analyzed by UPLC-MS (Waters 2695 with ACE C18 column 2.0 × 100 mm, 2.7 μm spherical particle size and Electrospray micromass ZQ-2000 from Waters). Data were analyzed using GraphPad Prism 7 using one-phase decay equation and represented the half-life of an experimental triplicate.

    In Vivo Analgesic Assay

    Animals and Housing

    Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats, weighing 225–300 g (Charles River laboratories, St Constant, Canada), were housed two per cage on Aspen shavings in a quiet room and kept on a 12 h light/dark cycle and allowed ad libitum access to food and water. All experimental procedures were approved by the Animal Care Committee of the Université de Sherbrooke in accordance with policies and directives of the Canadian Council on Animal Care. Furthermore, they were performed in agreement with the principles of ARRIVE and United States NIH (Animals in Research: Reporting In Vivo Experiments).(102) Three pain models in rats were selected to assess the antinociceptive effects of the compounds administered intrathecally.

    Intrathecal Administration

    Rats were lightly anesthetized with isoflurane/oxygen (Baxter Corporation, Mississauga, ON, Canada; 2 L/min) flow and injected intrathecally at the L5-L6 intervertebral space with 0.9% saline or doses ranging from 10 to 150 μg/kg tested compounds, diluted in 0.9% saline.

    Acute Pain: Tail-Flick Test

    Acute pain was assessed using the tail-flick test (Tail-Flick Analgesia meter V2.00, Columbus Instruments, Columbus, Ohio, USA), which measures heat-induced pain in animals and reflects the compound’s analgesic efficacy.(103) The test measures the animal sensitivity to a high-intensity light beam focused on the tail. The tail-flick apparatus was set at a light intensity of 6, with a preset cutoff of 10 s to avoid tissue damages. The latency to flick the tail out of the path of the light beam corresponds to the measure of pain sensitivity or analgesia. Before testing, animals were individually acclimatized to manipulations and the behavioral apparatus 5 min/day for three consecutive days. On the test day, latency baseline measure was taken before drug injection. Compound 4 was injected intrathecally at increasing doses ranging from 10 to 150 μg/kg, while morphine (Medisca, St-Laurent, Canada) was given subcutaneously (doses ranged from 1 to 10 mg/kg). Naloxone was injected intraperitoneally at 10 mg/kg 30 min before administration of macrocycle 4. Effects of the tested compounds on thermal nociception were assessed every 10 min for up to 60 min following administration and compared to saline. Tail-flick latencies were converted into the percent maximal possible effect (%MPE) at the time of maximal peak of analgesia. % MPE were calculated according to the following formula: %MPE = [(test latency) – (saline latency)]/[(cutoff) – (saline latency)] × 100. Data are expressed as mean ± SEM of five animals for each dose. The half-maximal effective dose (ED50) of the compound was determined on the %MPE, calculated for each dose. Then, ED50 values were determined using the dose–response stimulation log(agonist) vs response (four parameters).

    Tonic Pain: Formalin Test

    The analgesic effect was further assessed using the formalin test as a model of persistent pain. Before testing, animals were acclimatized to manipulations and to plexiglass chambers 30 min/day for three consecutive days. On test day, rats received a 50 μL injection of diluted formaldehyde (1.85%; i.e. 5% formalin; Bioshop, Burlington, Ontario) into the plantar surface of the right hind paw, 5 min after intrathecal injection of the tested compound at increasing doses ranging from 30 to 150 μg/kg or ziconotide (Prialt) at 1 μg/kg (Cayman Chemical Co.). Rats were then placed in clear plexiglass chambers (30 × 30 × 30 cm) positioned over a mirror angled at 45° in order to allow an unobstructed view of the paws, and their behaviors were observed for the next 60 min. The intraplantar injection of formalin produced a biphasic nociceptive response typical of this tonic pain model.(85) These two distinct phases of spontaneous pain behaviors are proposed to reflect a short and direct effect of formalin on sensory receptors (acute phase, 0–9 min) and a longer lasting effect due to inflammation and central sensitization (inflammatory phase, 21–60 min). Nociceptive behaviors were assessed using a weighted score, as described previously.(104) Following injection of formalin, nociceptive mean score was determined for each 3 min block during 60 min by measuring the amount of time spent in each of four behavioral categories: 0, before the formalin injection, the injected paw is similar to the contralateral paw; 1, the injected paw has little weight placed on it; 2, the injected paw is elevated and is not in contact with any surface (lifting); 3, the injected paw is licked, bitten, or shaken.(105) Reduction in time spent in lifting was chosen to follow the analgesic effectiveness of compound 4 or ziconotide, as previously described with NTS2-selective agonists.(86) Data represents the mean ± SEM of five rats for each dose.

    Chronic Pain: CFA Model

    Chronic inflammatory pain was induced with an intraplantar injection of 100 μL of complete Freund’s adjuvant (CFA) in the plantar surface of the left hind paw of rats. The injected volume (injected as a 1:1 emulsion of oil and saline 0.9%) contained the equivalent of 200 μg of lyophilized bacterial membranes (Mycobacterium butyricum) for a final concentration of 8 mg/mL. Intraplantar injection of saline 0.9% was performed on sham animals. CFA injections were performed under isoflurane/oxygen anesthesia. Rats were acclimatized to the plexiglass enclosures, the mesh floor, and the filament for 3 days prior to testing. On test day, rats were given 10 min to habituate to the enclosures. The von Frey test was performed before (day 0) and 3, 7, and 14 days after CFA injection. Allodynia was evaluated using calibrated von Frey hairs. The blunt filaments were applied against the mid-plantar surface of the hind paw. Filaments with increasing resistance were used ranging from 2 to 15 g. Paw withdrawal threshold (PWT) was then determined as previously described.(106) A 15 g force was considered as the upper cutoff. Five values were taken alternately on both ipsilateral and contralateral hind paws at intervals of 7 s. The effect of 150 μg/kg of the compound or saline on mechanical allodynia was assessed at 15, 30, 60, and 120 min following i.t. administration on days 7 and 14. The percentage of antiallodynic effect was calculated according to the following formula: % antiallodynic effect = 100 × (PWTcompound – PWTsaline)/(PWTsham – PWTsaline). Data represents the mean ± SEM of six rats for each condition.

    Other Physiological Effects

    Blood Pressure Measurements

    Rats were anesthetized with ketamine/xylazine (87 mg/kg: 13 mg/kg, i.m.) and placed in supine position on a heating pad. Mean arterial blood pressure (MABP) was measured through a catheter (PE 50 filled with heparinized saline) inserted in the right carotid artery and connected to a Micro-Med transducer (model TDX-300, USA) linked to a blood pressure Micro-Med analyzer (model BPA-100c). Another catheter (PE 10 filled with heparinized saline) was inserted into the left jugular vein for bolus injection of 0.9% saline or the compound at either 0.01, 0.1, or 1 mg/kg (volume 1 mL/kg, 5–10 s). Blood pressure was recorded each second for up to 1000 s following intravenous injection. Changes in mean arterial blood pressure (ΔMABP) were determined from the basal MABP of the animal. Data represents the mean ± SEM of five rats for each dose.

    Body Temperature

    Body temperature was measured using a thermistor probe inserted into the rat’s rectum. Prior to testing, animals were individually acclimatized to manipulations and the thermistor probe for 5 min/day for three consecutive days. Temperatures were then measured before (baseline) and every 10 min for up to 60 min following intrathecal drug administration. The compound was dissolved in 0.9% of saline and injected at the highest analgesic dose of 150 μg/kg. Changes in body temperature (Δbody temperature) were determined from the baseline for each time and each animal. Data represents the mean ± SEM of six rats for each condition.

    Ex Vivo Ileum Relaxation Assay

    Smooth muscle relaxation assays of distal rat ileum were performed in isolated organ baths. Rats were anesthetized using ketamine/xylazine (87 mg/kg: 13 mg/kg, i.m.) and euthanized by surgical rupture of thoracic aorta. Tissues were rapidly removed, cut into 1 cm-long strips, cleaned of fat, and mounted vertically in 15 mL baths. The baths were filled with oxygenated (95% O2 and 5% CO2) and thermoregulated (37 ̊C) Krebs solution (NaCl 118.1 mmol/L, KCl 4.7 mmol/L, CaCl2 2.5 mmol/L, KH2PO4 1.2 mmol/L, MgSO4 1.2 mmol/L, NaHCO3 25 mmol/L, and d-glucose 5.5 mmol/L; pH 7.4). Strips were stretched with a resting tension of 1.0 gram followed by an equilibration period of at least 60 min with replacement of the Krebs solution every 15 min. At the beginning of each experiment, ileum preparations were challenged with 100 nM carbachol until a constant contractile response was achieved, with multiple washing between stimulation. Tissues were then pre-contracted with the same dose of carbachol and tested with analog concentrations ranging from 10–11 to 10–5 M. Non-cumulative concentration–response curves for NT analogs were established; thus, analogs were added to the baths as a single addition following washout of the previous dose. Muscular contractions were measured isometrically with force transducers (Radnoti Glass Technology Inc.), recorded on multichannel chart recorders (PowerLab 8/30, ADInstruments) linked to the LabChart Pro software (version 8.1.8). The percentage of ileum relaxation was calculated against each individual contraction. EC50 values were determined using the dose–response stimulation log(agonist) vs response (four parameters) in GraphPad Prism 7 and presented as mean ± SEM of three different experiments.

    Statistical Analyses

    All experimental protocols, data, and statistical analyses in this study comply with the recommendations on experimental design and analysis in pharmacology.(107) Animals were randomized to treatment groups. For the behavioral tests, baselines in the tail-flick test, AUCs of the pain scores in the formalin test, and baselines of paw withdrawal threshold on days 7 and 14 in the von Frey test followed a normal (or Gaussian) distribution determined by the Shapiro–Wilk normality test. Parametric tests were thus performed to increase statistical power. Power analysis estimated sample sizes of 2.2 rats per group for the tail-flick and formalin tests and 3.5 rats per group for the von Frey test. For ANOVA analysis, post-hoc tests were conducted only if F was significant and there was no variance in homogeneity. Data are expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). All graphs and statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism 7 (GraphPad software, La Jolla, CA, USA). For binding affinities, Ki values ± SEM were calculated from the IC50 values, which were derived from the resulting dose–response curves.
    A two-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett’s multiple comparison test was used to determine the significance differences in tail-flick latency, paw withdrawal threshold, and changes in body temperature between saline and different doses of compound 4 or morphine as well as between saline and PD149163 or compound 4 (*). A two-way ANOVA followed by Dunnett’s multiple comparison test was used to determine significant differences in the paw withdrawal threshold between sham animals and CFA-treated rats receiving saline (#). The %MPE, the time spent in lifting in the formalin test, and the % of antiallodynic effect were analyzed using a one-way ANOVA followed by a Dunnett’s multiple comparison test to compare the effect of different doses of compound 4 or ziconotide with saline. To determine the half-maximal effective dose (ED50) of the compound, the %MPE in acute pain was calculated for each dose of the compound. Then, ED50 values were determined using the dose–response stimulation log(agonist) vs response (four parameters). Nonlinear regression using three parameters was also performed to determine the half-maximal inhibitory concentration (EC50) of neurotensin in the ileum relaxation assay. A difference in response between compound 4 and saline was considered significant with p-values *p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001, and ****p < 0.0001. A difference in response between sham animals and CFA rats treated with saline was considered significant with p-value ####p < 0.0001.

    complete Freund’s adjuvant

    CNS

    central nervous system

    CSF

    cerebrospinal fluid

    EC50

    half-maximal effective concentration

    ED50

    half-maximal effective dose

    IC50

    concentration inhibiting 50% of binding

    i.m.

    intramuscular

    i.t.

    intrathecal

    i.v.

    intravenous

    MABP

    mean arterial blood pressure

    %MPE

    % maximal possible effect

    NT

    neurotensin

    NTS1

    neurotensin receptor type 1

    neurotensin receptor type 2

    paw withdrawal threshold

    structure–activity relationship

    ring-closing metathesis

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 107 other publications.

    1. 1
      de Leon-Casasola, O. A. Opioids for Chronic Pain: New Evidence, New Strategies, Safe Prescribing. Am. J. Med. 2013, 126, S3– S11,  DOI: 10.1016/j.amjmed.2012.11.011
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Opioids for Chronic Pain: New Evidence, New Strategies, Safe Prescribing
      de Leon-Casasola, Oscar A.
      American Journal of Medicine (2013), 126 (3, Suppl. 1), S3-S11CODEN: AJMEAZ; ISSN:0002-9343. (Elsevier)
      A review. In the United States, the prevalence and burden of chronic pain is large and still growing. Older adults (aged ≥65 years) make up a large portion of the population with chronic pain, and their presentation, diagnosis, and treatment tends to be more complicated because of age-related physiol. changes and comorbidities. Guidelines on treating patients with severe back pain recommend opioids as an option for those who do not find adequate pain relief from acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For older adult patients at higher risk for NSAID-related adverse effects, such as those who have gastrointestinal or cardiovascular disease, diabetes mellitus, or who are taking low-dose aspirin, opioids are recommended instead. Opioids may also be an appropriate option for patients with neuropathic pain who have not achieved adequate analgesia from max. doses of first- and second-line antineuropathic agents. Still, opioids are not appropriate for all patients; rather, a differential diagnosis, consideration of other comorbidities, and the potential for opioid-related adverse effects and substance abuse are required to confirm the value of opioid treatment for each individual. For nonresponders to opioid therapy, opioid rotation should be considered before discontinuation is pursued.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXjt1Sgsr8%253D&md5=03d6831cc14515153cf4040a31a053a2
    2. 2
      Balch, R. J.; Trescot, A. Extended-Release Morphine Sulfate in Treatment of Severe Acute and Chronic Pain. J. Pain. Res. 2010, 3, 191– 200,  DOI: 10.2147/JPR.S6529
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Extended-release morphine sulfate in treatment of severe acute and chronic pain
      Balch, Robert J.; Trescot, Andrea
      Journal of Pain Research (2010), 3 (), 191-200CODEN: JPROEV; ISSN:1178-7090. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
      A review. Morphine is the archetypal opioid analgesic. Because it is a short-acting opioid, its use has been limited to the management of acute pain. The development of extended-release formulations have resulted in the increased utilization of morphine in chronic pain conditions. This review documents the history of morphine use in pain treatment, and describes the metab., pharmacodynamics, formulations, and efficacy of the currently available extended-release morphine medications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXht1SksLzM&md5=4168f806d9bca0b7511d17102e49ef5c
    3. 3
      Stein, C. Opioid Analgesia: Recent Developments. Curr. Opin. Supportive Palliative Care 2020, 14, 112– 117,  DOI: 10.1097/SPC.0000000000000495
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Opioid analgesia: recent developments
      Stein Christoph
      Current opinion in supportive and palliative care (2020), 14 (2), 112-117 ISSN:.
      PURPOSE OF REVIEW: Opioids are potent drugs for the treatment of severe pain, but they are burdened by detrimental side-effects, such as respiratory depression, addiction, sedation and constipation. Their clinical application is undisputed in acute (e.g. perioperative) and cancer pain, but their use in chronic nonmalignant pain has met increasing scrutiny and has contributed to the opioid crisis. Thus, novel analgesics with reduced side-effects are badly needed. RECENT FINDINGS: Current research topics include enkephalinase inhibitors, allosteric and multivalent ligands, biased opioid receptor signaling and selective activation of peripheral opioid receptors in injured tissues. SUMMARY: Opioids still appear to be most promising among current approaches in the development of analgesics. Basic knowledge about pathophysiology of clinical pain and novel insights in pharmacology suggest that the most interesting perspectives are augmenting endogenous opioid actions and selectively targeting peripheral opioid receptors. The latter approach is additionally supported by evidence from clinical studies. Some biased, multivalent and peripherally selective agonists have advanced to phase III trials, but novel drugs have not become available for clinical application. Future strategies in analgesic drug development might include public-private partnerships and nonprofit pharmaceutical companies, as exemplified by the AIDS crisis and proposals to combat antibiotic resistance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB38zms1aruw%253D%253D&md5=4b9674952ab21b82a438efc5299af472
    4. 4
      Fornasari, D.; Allegri, M.; Gerboni, S.; Fanelli, G. A ″Novel″ Association to Treat Pain: Tramadol/Dexketoprofen. The First Drug of a ″New Pharmacological Class″. Acta Biomed. 2017, 88, 17– 24,  DOI: 10.23750/abm.v88i1.6361
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      A "novel" association to treat pain: tramadol/dexketoprofen. The first drug of a "new pharmacological class"
      Fornasari, D.; Allegri, M.; Gerboni, S.; Fanelli, G.
      Acta Bio Medica Atenei Parmensis (2017), 88 (1), 17-24CODEN: ABMAC3 ISSN:. (Mattioli 1885)
      Acute and chronic pain have an important socio-economical impact. In order to help physicians to choose the appropriate drug, esp. for cancer pain, in 1986 WHO has developed a three-step analgesic "ladder" for cancer pain relief in adults. Later it has also been used for acute pain and chronic non-cancer pain. In step I nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are considered with or without adjuvants, in step II the use of weak opioids for mild-moderate pain, with or without NSAIDs and adjuvant, is suggested, while the step III is reserved to strong opioids for moderate-severe pain with or without non-opioids or adjuvants. In the last two decades, a better pathophysiol. knowledge has improved pain management shifting our view from the pain ladder to a modern pain pyramid, in which drugs are selected not only on the basis of pain intensity, but mainly according to mechanisms underlying pain, including peripheral and spinal sensitization which is the main trigger of chronic pain. The best pharmacol. approach has become multimodal, in which drugs belonging to different steps should be combined, matching the mechanisms of action with the type of pain. An important corollary of combining analgesic drugs with different mechanism of action is that proper matching achieves the same effect with lower doses, better outcome and fewer adverse effects. In this new perspective, fixed-dose pharmaceutical combinations of different drugs are very useful to fulfil pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics and adherence criteria, enriching the pain pyramid of half-steps between the first and second step and between the second and third step. Hence, a new fixed combination of a NSAID with peripheral and central anti-infilammatory activities, such as dexketoprofen, and a weak opioid, such as tramadol, with double analgesic activity in the spinal cord as an opioid and, at the same time, on the descending modulatory pathways, is expected to cover a wide range of acute and recurrent painful conditions, ranging from nociceptive inflammatory pain to neuropathic pain of moderate/severe intensity. In this review we evaluate the rationale that justifies its use as new class of pharmacol. modality to treat pain accordingly also to a more update view of WHO pain ladder.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvFOku7rP&md5=7d30261335f53036ff02f116a1ae649f
    5. 5
      Finnerup, N. B.; Attal, N.; Haroutounian, S.; McNicol, E.; Baron, R.; Dworkin, R. H.; Gilron, I.; Haanpää, M.; Hansson, P.; Jensen, T. S.; Kamerman, P. R.; Lund, K.; Moore, A.; Raja, S. N.; Rice, A. S. C.; Rowbotham, M.; Sena, E.; Siddall, P.; Smith, B. H.; Wallace, M. Pharmacotherapy for Neuropathic Pain in Adults: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Lancet Neurol. 2015, 14, 162– 173,  DOI: 10.1016/S1474-4422(14)70251-0
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      Pharmacotherapy for neuropathic pain in adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis
      Finnerup, Nanna B.; Attal, Nadine; Haroutounian, Simon; McNicol, Ewan; Baron, Ralf; Dworkin, Robert H.; Gilron, Ian; Haanpaa, Maija; Hansson, Per; Jensen, Troels S.; Kamerman, Peter R.; Lund, Karen; Moore, Andrew; Raja, Srinivasa N.; Rice, Andrew S. C.; Rowbotham, Michael; Sena, Emily; Siddall, Philip; Smith, Blair H.; Wallace, Mark
      Lancet Neurology (2015), 14 (2), 162-173CODEN: LNAEAM; ISSN:1474-4422. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      New drug treatments, clin. trials, and stds. of quality for assessment of evidence justify an update of evidence-based recommendations for the pharmacol. treatment of neuropathic pain. Using the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE), we revised the Special Interest Group on Neuropathic Pain (NeuPSIG) recommendations for the pharmacotherapy of neuropathic pain based on the results of a systematic review and meta-anal. Between Apr., 2013, and Jan., 2014, NeuPSIG of the International Assocn. for the Study of Pain did a systematic review and meta-anal. of randomised, double-blind studies of oral and topical pharmacotherapy for neuropathic pain, including studies published in peer-reviewed journals since Jan., 1966, and unpublished trials retrieved from ClinicalTrials.gov and websites of pharmaceutical companies. We used no. needed to treat (NNT) for 50% pain relief as a primary measure and assessed publication bias; NNT was calcd. with the fixed-effects Mantel-Haenszel method.229 studies were included in the meta-anal. Anal. of publication bias suggested a 10% overstatement of treatment effects. Studies published in peer-reviewed journals reported greater effects than did unpublished studies (r2 9·3%, p=0·009). Trial outcomes were generally modest: in particular, combined NNTs were 6·4 (95% CI 5·2-8·4) for serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors, mainly including duloxetine (nine of 14 studies); 7·7 (6·5-9·4) for pregabalin; 7·2 (5·9-9·21) for gabapentin, including gabapentin extended release and enacarbil; and 10·6 (7·4-19·0) for capsaicin high-concn. patches. NNTs were lower for tricyclic antidepressants, strong opioids, tramadol, and botulinum toxin A, and undetd. for lidocaine patches. Based on GRADE, final quality of evidence was moderate or high for all treatments apart from lidocaine patches; tolerability and safety, and values and preferences were higher for topical drugs; and cost was lower for tricyclic antidepressants and tramadol. These findings permitted a strong recommendation for use and proposal as first-line treatment in neuropathic pain for tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors, pregabalin, and gabapentin; a weak recommendation for use and proposal as second line for lidocaine patches, capsaicin high-concn. patches, and tramadol; and a weak recommendation for use and proposal as third line for strong opioids and botulinum toxin A. Topical agents and botulinum toxin A are recommended for peripheral neuropathic pain only. Our results support a revision of the NeuPSIG recommendations for the pharmacotherapy of neuropathic pain. Inadequate response to drug treatments constitutes a substantial unmet need in patients with neuropathic pain. Modest efficacy, large placebo responses, heterogeneous diagnostic criteria, and poor phenotypic profiling probably account for moderate trial outcomes and should be taken into account in future studies. NeuPSIG of the International Assocn. for the Study of Pain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXovFygsw%253D%253D&md5=aaae3dd82ea6896d3977412faedebffd
    6. 6
      Attal, N.; Bouhassira, D. Pharmacotherapy of Neuropathic Pain: Which Drugs, Which Treatment Algorithms?. Pain 2015, 156, S104– S114,  DOI: 10.1097/01.j.pain.0000460358.01998.15
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar

    7. 7
      Afsharimani, B.; Kindl, K.; Good, P.; Hardy, J. Pharmacological Options for the Management of Refractory Cancer Pain-What Is the Evidence?. Support Care Cancer 2015, 23, 1473– 1481,  DOI: 10.1007/s00520-015-2678-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Pharmacological options for the management of refractory cancer pain-what is the evidence?
      Afsharimani B; Kindl K; Good P; Hardy J
      Supportive care in cancer : official journal of the Multinational Association of Supportive Care in Cancer (2015), 23 (5), 1473-81 ISSN:.
      Refractory cancer pain that does not respond to standard opioid and/or co-analgesic therapy occurs in 10-20 % of patients. Risk factors include young age, neuropathic pain type, incident pain, psychological distress, previous opioid use, high tolerance, a history of addiction and impaired cognition. The management of patients with refractory pain remains a challenge. Treatment options include opioid manipulation (parenteral delivery, rotation, combination, methadone and buprenorphine), non-opioids and co-analgesics (paracetamol, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents, antidepressants and anticonvulsants), NMDA receptor antagonists, cannabinoids, lignocaine and corticosteroids. The evidence of benefit for any of these agents is weak, and each additional agent increases the risk of adverse events. Evidence-based guidelines cannot, therefore, be developed at present. New approaches are recommended including targeted opioid therapy, multimodal analgesia, a goal-oriented approach to pain management and increasing use of the multidisciplinary team and support services.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2MnitFGktg%253D%253D&md5=7a437a90f384fba6f4615d181cd120e2
    8. 8
      Benyamin, R.; Trescot, A. M.; Datta, S.; Buenaventura, R.; Adlaka, R.; Sehgal, N.; Glaser, S. E.; Vallejo, R. Opioid Complications and Side Effects. Pain Physician 2008, 11, S105– S120
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Opioid complications and side effects
      Benyamin Ramsin; Trescot Andrea M; Datta Sukdeb; Buenaventura Ricardo; Adlaka Rajive; Sehgal Nalini; Glaser Scott E; Vallejo Ricardo
      Pain physician (2008), 11 (2 Suppl), S105-20 ISSN:1533-3159.
      Medications which bind to opioid receptors are increasingly being prescribed for the treatment of multiple and diverse chronic painful conditions. Their use for acute pain or terminal pain is well accepted. Their role in the long-term treatment of chronic noncancer pain is, however, controversial for many reasons. One of the primary reasons is the well-known phenomenon of psychological addiction that can occur with the use of these medications. Abuse and diversion of these medications is a growing problem as the availability of these medications increases and this public health issue confounds their clinical utility. Also, the extent of their efficacy in the treatment of pain when utilized on a chronic basis has not been definitively proven. Lastly, the role of opioids in the treatment of chronic pain is also influenced by the fact that these potent analgesics are associated with a significant number of side effects and complications. It is these phenomena that are the focus of this review. Common side effects of opioid administration include sedation, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, constipation, physical dependence, tolerance, and respiratory depression. Physical dependence and addiction are clinical concerns that may prevent proper prescribing and in turn inadequate pain management. Less common side effects may include delayed gastric emptying, hyperalgesia, immunologic and hormonal dysfunction, muscle rigidity, and myoclonus. The most common side effects of opioid usage are constipation (which has a very high incidence) and nausea. These 2 side effects can be difficult to manage and frequently tolerance to them does not develop; this is especially true for constipation. They may be severe enough to require opioid discontinuation, and contribute to under-dosing and inadequate analgesia. Several clinical trials are underway to identify adjunct therapies that may mitigate these side effects. Switching opioids and/or routes of administration may also provide benefits for patients. Proper patient screening, education, and preemptive treatment of potential side effects may aid in maximizing effectiveness while reducing the severity of side effects and adverse events. Opioids can be considered broad spectrum analgesic agents, affecting a wide number of organ systems and influencing a large number of body functions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD1czosVSjsQ%253D%253D&md5=26196f3cc302b1cad86e32477bb52e18
    9. 9
      Chu, L. F.; Clark, D. J.; Angst, M. S. Opioid Tolerance and Hyperalgesia in Chronic Pain Patients after One Month of Oral Morphine Therapy: A Preliminary Prospective Study. J. Pain 2006, 7, 43– 48,  DOI: 10.1016/j.jpain.2005.08.001
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Opioid Tolerance and Hyperalgesia in Chronic Pain Patients After One Month of Oral Morphine Therapy: A Preliminary Prospective Study
      Chu, Larry F.; Clark, David J.; Angst, Martin S.
      Journal of Pain (2006), 7 (1), 43-48CODEN: JPOAB5; ISSN:1526-5900. (Elsevier Inc.)
      There is accumulating evidence that opioid therapy might not only be assocd. with the development of tolerance but also with an increased sensitivity to pain, a condition referred to as opioid-induced hyperalgesia (OIH). However, there are no prospective studies documenting the development of opioid tolerance or OIH in patients with chronic pain. This preliminary study in 6 patients with chronic low back pain prospectively evaluated the development of tolerance and OIH. Patients were assessed before and 1 mo after initiating oral morphine therapy. The cold pressor test and exptl. heat pain were used to measure pain sensitivity before and during a target-controlled infusion with the short-acting μ opioid agonist remifentanil. In the cold pressor test, all patients became hyperalgesic as well as tolerant after 1 mo of oral morphine therapy. In a model of heat pain, patients exhibited no hyperalgesia, although tolerance could not be evaluated. These results provide the first prospective evidence for the development of analgesic tolerance and OIH by using exptl. pain in patients with chronic back pain. This study also validated methodol. for prospectively studying these phenomena in larger populations of pain patients. Perspective: Exptl. evidence suggests that opioid tolerance and opioid-induced hyperalgesia might limit the clin. utility of opioids in controlling chronic pain. This study validates a pharmacol. approach to study these phenomena prospectively in chronic pain patients and suggests that both conditions do occur within 1 mo of initiating opioid therapy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xls1Wgtg%253D%253D&md5=1aec558cf8dc6754af4dea1370cdcfb0
    10. 10
      Munzing, T. Physician Guide to Appropriate Opioid Prescribing for Noncancer Pain. Perm. J. 2017, 21, 16– 169,  DOI: 10.7812/TPP/16-169
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Physician Guide to Appropriate Opioid Prescribing for Noncancer Pain
      Munzing Timothy
      The Permanente journal (2017), 21 (), 16-169 ISSN:.
      Prescription opioid use for relief of noncancer pain has risen dramatically in the last 15 years, contributing to a quadrupling of opioid overdoses and prescription opioid-related deaths. This crisis is resulting in heightened attention by health care professionals and organizations, law enforcement, and the government. In this article, I highlight key topics in the management of patients using opioids (or potentially needing opioids) in outpatient clinical practice; federal and state law enforcement actions regarding physicians' illegal prescribing of opioids; multimodal approaches to pain control; nonmedication management of pain; response strategies when suspecting a patient of diverting or misusing opioids; and warning signs for abuse or diversion. For those patients for whom opioids are appropriate, I describe key elements for prescribing, including documentation of a detailed history and examination, appropriate evaluation to arrive at a specific diagnosis, individualizing management, and ongoing monitoring (including the use of urine drug screening and a prescription drug monitoring program). In addition to individual action, when possible, the initiation of systemwide and clinicwide safe prescribing practices supports the physician and patient such that the patient's well-being is at the heart of all pain management decisions. Physicians are encouraged to further educate themselves to treat pain safely and effectively; to screen patients for opioid use disorder and, when diagnosed, to connect them with evidence-based treatment; and to follow Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines whenever possible.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1crlslGrtg%253D%253D&md5=6dae0a55c50da02aa9a36858cefdd746
    11. 11
      Coyle, D. T.; Pratt, C. Y.; Ocran-Appiah, J.; Secora, A.; Kornegay, C.; Staffa, J. Opioid Analgesic Dose and the Risk of Misuse, Overdose, and Death: A Narrative Review. Pharmacoepidemiol. Drug. Saf. 2018, 27, 464– 472,  DOI: 10.1002/pds.4366
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Opioid analgesic dose and the risk of misuse, overdose, and death: A narrative review
      Coyle David Tyler; Pratt Chih-Ying; Ocran-Appiah Josephine; Secora Alex; Kornegay Cynthia; Staffa Judy
      Pharmacoepidemiology and drug safety (2018), 27 (5), 464-472 ISSN:.
      PURPOSE: Despite the rise in serious adverse events paralleling increased prescription opioid analgesic use in the United States over the past 2 decades, the association between opioid analgesic dose and the risk of serious adverse health outcomes is incompletely characterized. We sought to synthesize the medical literature for observational studies examining the association between opioid analgesic dose and the risk of serious adverse health outcomes, with particular attention to the outcomes of misuse, abuse, addiction, overdose, and death. METHODS: Searching MEDLINE using PubMed and bibliography review, we identified 22 observational studies published between 2000 and 2015 that assessed the association between opioid analgesic dose and the risk of serious adverse health outcomes. Some of these studies had significant methodological limitations. Twelve reviewed studies examined the outcomes of misuse, overdose, or death; no studies examining the risk of addiction or abuse met our criteria for inclusion. RESULTS: The results of multiple studies clearly indicate an increasing risk of serious adverse health outcomes associated with increasing opioid analgesic dose. In particular, the risk of misuse, overdose, and death increases with increasing opioid analgesic dose. However, there is no opioid dose inflection point beyond which the risk of these adverse health outcomes increases. No opioid analgesic dose is without risk. CONCLUSIONS: The reviewed studies show an increasing risk of serious adverse health outcomes-including misuse, overdose, and death-associated with increasing opioid analgesic dose. Further research is needed to characterize the relationship between opioid analgesic dose and the risk of addiction and abuse. This analysis could inform policy actions for regulators and clinical decision making for providers.

      Carraway, R.; Leeman, S. E. The Isolation of a New Hypotensive Peptide, Neurotensin, from Bovine Hypothalami. J. Biol. Chem. 1973, 248, 6854– 6861,  DOI: 10.1016/S0021-9258(19)43429-7
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Isolation of a new hypotensive peptide, neurotensin, from bovine hypothalami
      Carraway, Robert; Leeman, Susan E.
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (1973), 248 (19), 6854-61CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258.
      A hypotensive peptide, designated neurotensin, was isolated in pure form from acid-Me2CO exts. of bovine hypothalami by column chromatog. and paper electrophoresis. Amino acid anal. of material recovered after paper electrophoresis at pH 3.5, 6.5, and 8.9 and chromatog. anal. of the dansylated material indicated that the peptide isolated by this procedure was homogenous. Its amino acid compn. and apparent mol. wt. estd. by chromatog. on Sephadex G-25 indicated that neurotensin is a tridecapeptide composed of Lys, Arg2, Asx, Glx2, Pro2, Ileu, Leu2, Tyr2. Neurotensin lacks a free N-terminus; however, it possesses a free C-terminus which can be acted upon by carboxypeptidase A. Neurotensin induced hypotension in the rat and stimulated the contraction of guinea pig ileum and rat uterus; however, it produced relaxation of the rat duodenum. These pharmacol. properties classify it as a kinin, yet its chem. compn. distinguishes it from any known peptide.

      Granier, C.; Van Rietschoten, J.; Kitabgi, P.; Poustis, C.; Freychet, P. Synthesis and Characterization of Neurotensin Analogues for Structure/Activity Relationship Studies. Acetyl-Neurotensin-(8–13) Is the Shortest Analogue with Full Binding and Pharmacological Activities. Eur. J. Biochem. 1982, 124, 117– 125,  DOI: 10.1111/j.1432-1033.1982.tb05913.x
